head.p: This catalogue covers 1251 loose prints (100x75mm) from the Stein Collection, Third Expedition, 1913-16. The series can be broken down chronologically as follows:

msItem.title: Boats starting from left bank, Indus at Hodar.

note.p: View looking down onto a raft made from inflated bullock skins: 'The heat of the summer is great in the deep-cut rock defiles of the Indus, and the banks forbiddingly barren. So I was glad when our descent in the Indus gorge next day could be effected on a skin raft which the tossing current of the mighty river carried down at a rate of some 14 miles an hour...' (A third journey..., p. 5).
Hodar; India/Pakistan disputed territory; Indus (river); Kashmir

msItem.title: Kino-kot ruins seen from west, south-east of Balugush.

note.p: View towards ruined fort at summit of hill: 'At the mouth of the Hodur stream we left the Indus behind and entered ground which offered ample scope for exploring work. Passing up the unsurveyed valley northward we found plentiful ruins of small fortified villages clearly dating back to pre-Muhammadan times...' (A third journey..., pp. 5-6). PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig. 5: 'Ruined site of Kino-kot at mouth of Hodar Valley.'

msItem.title: Tibetan inscription and stupa, Darkot Pass.

note.p: Close view of rock with carved inscrption and stupa image. '...It was a particularly gratifying find when I discovered an old Tibetan inscription scratched deep into a large boulder on the track where it ascends by the side of a steep moraine flanking the southern glacier of the Darkot. It is very probable that it is a relic of that short-lived Tibetan advance on the uppermost Oxus which the T'ang Annals record towards the close of the second quarter of the eighth century, and which Kao Hsien-chih's adventurous expedition successfully stopped.' ('A third journey...', p. 12). Another view at print 125. PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig. 46: 'Engraved boulder with stupa design and Tibetan inscription on ascent to Darkot Pass.'
Darkot Pass; North-West Frontier Province; Pakistan

msItem.title: Karambar Pass panorama (Section IV). South-south-east. Karambar Glacier with snout.

note.p: Fourth section of six-part panoramic view. The complete panorama comprises prints 135-140. PUBLISHED: 'A third journey of exploration...', fig. 5: 'Panoramic view taken from Karambar Saddle (circ. 14,050 feet above sea level) dividing headwaters of Karambar and Yarkhun, or Mastuj Rivers. The view extends from north-east, on extreme left (main Hindukush watershed towards Oxus), to west-south-west, on extreme right (uppermost Yarkhun Valley).' Topographical features also marked on the published version are: East Karambar Glacier, with bifurcating drainage; main Karambar Glacier feeding Yarkhun River; Glaciers above Murghach; peaks above Darkot and Chatiboi Glaciers.
Karambar Glacier; Karambar Pass; North-West Frontier Province; Pakistan

msItem.title: Yarkand River and Mazar-tagh from ford, right bank.

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig. 81: 'View towards Mazar-tagh from across Yarkand River.' (I.A. Map 8, A-B1). This is the peak just south-east of Maral-bashi, not the Mazar-tagh on the Khotan River which Stein was planning to reach across the Taklamakan. See note at print 226.

msItem.title: Yarakand River and Chok-tagh from Lempe-kotan.
Camels (free) and string behind crossing deep portion of Yarkand River towards Chok-tagh.

note.p: View looking towards the two groups of animals crossing the river near Kuruk-aste (I.A. Map 8, A1). This photograph was taken at the start of Stein's abortive attempt to reach the Mazar-tagh range on the Khotan River by heading directly south-east across the Taklamakan Desert from Maral-bashi. In addition to the advantages of gaining time by this short-cut, 'and the attraction presented by such a venture across an unknown tract of desert' (i, 81), Stein hoped to establish that the Mazar-tagh hills on the Khotan River were part of the same geological structure as the hills of the same name south-east of Maral-bashi. However, the harsh climbing over massive dunes took a heavy toll on the strength of Stein's camels and on 31 October he relates that 'more disquieting still was the fact that in the course of a ten hours' tramp extending over eleven miles as measured by the cyclometer we had not succeeded in covering more than a little over seven miles of direct distance.' (i, 87). The attempt was abandoned at Camp XXVIII on 1 November.

msItem.title: Camels crossing the Yarkand River towards Chok-tagh.

note.p: Taken on the same occasion as print 226 (I.A. Map 8, A1). Chok-tagh was the peak to the south of the river, on the way to Camp XXVIII.

msItem.title: Kasim Akhun, Tokhta Marghen, Tokhta Akhun of Islamabad and Dash, hunters at Sarghan-och.

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig. 86: 'Kasim Akhun, Aziz Pawan, and Tokhta-Akhun.' Kasim Akhun standing on left: 'Ever since my expedition to Dandan-oilik in 1900 I had learned to value and trust the pluck, sense of locality, and true desert instinct that a lifetime spent in hunting trips and other lonely wanderings in the Taklamakan had bred in this wiry and ever resolute man.' (i. 82). The different identification of the central figure in the published version appears to be incorrect, since the central figure is not the same man portrayed in print 270 and there identified as Aziz Pawan. Sarghan-och has not been traced on the map, although it must be in the vicinity of Maral-bashi.

Earthwork started on tugh above Tlkch-kl. [At Khanaka-tokai.]

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig. 105: 'Men at work on new barrage across flood-bed above Tulkuch-tarim.' (I.A. Map 19, B1). On his arrival at Tulkuch-kol Stein found that floods of recent years threatened the existence of the small colony, by destroying a barrage of the irrigation canal which brought water to the fields. 'I may mention that my timely return to the Niya site incidentally offered a chance of saving the Tulkuch-tarim. My resumed excavations had brought a comparatively large force of able-bodied labourers near the spot. So when I had returned with them from the ruins and was leaving for Charchan I was glad to set them to work to raise a new tugh across the deep-cut flood-bed at the point where Nurullah's previosu effort had failed....' (i, 141).

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig. 106: 'Men of Vash-shahri guarding route from Charchan.' 'After leaving Tatran we did not meet with a single wayfarer, which struck me as strange at the time and left me in doubts as to the situation we might find at Charkhlik. But when approaching on January 6th the jungle belt which from the west screens the ruined site of Vash-shahri...we found the route guarded by a large party of armed Muhammadans who at first from a distance mistook us for a fresh batch of 'revolutionaries' and were preparing to resist...Fortunately the mistake was promptly cleared up...' (i, 159). (I.A. Map 26, C3).

msItem.title: Sher Ali Khan and his companions arrive from Ssu-chuen. [Miran.]

note.p: Full-length portrait of the three men standing in front of stupa remains at Miran. PUBLISHED: ' Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig. 121: 'Sher Ali Khan, Bajauri trader, with two travel companions.' Sher Ali Khan's arrival at Miran was fortunate: Stein had just received news from Sir George Macartney that the provincial government at Urumchi had issued an edict ordering all district authorities to prevent his carrying out further survey work, and if necessary to arrest him and escort him back to Kashgar. Although these orders did not get through to the officials in direct contact with Stein and thus did not affect his work, they prevented new camels being sent out to him from Charkhlik. The trader Sher Ali Khan ('this hardy and intelligent Pathan' whom Stein had first met at Dunhuang in 1907) fortunately at this point arrived with a caravan of forty camels on his biennial journey from Ssu-chuan to Yarkand, and agreed to supply Stein with the necessary animals. (i, 176-77). (I.A. Map 30, B2).

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig 153: 'Eroded terraces bearing remains of foundation of north wall, L.A. station. (See p. 215, note, regarding dead tamarisk stems).' This note reads: 'Fig. 153 exhibits the few portions of the northern (strictly west-north-west) face where remains of the wall foundation, in the shape of tamarisk fascines, are still traceable, marking the original ground level. The small dead tamarisk stems in the foreground of Fig. 153 are of interest. They had grown up and died young on ground which had been eroded already to a depth of some 20 feet below the original level, presumably at a time when subsoil water had again temporarily approached the site.' (I.A. Map 29, D3).

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig 157: 'North end of eroded terrace bearing foundation of east wall, L.A. station. (See p. 215, note 3.)' This note reads (in part): 'In Fig. 157 the north end of the same [east-north-east] wall segment is seen, with the layer of tamarisk brushwood which has prevented complete erosion. On the right appears a small tamarisk-cone which had grown up later on wind-eroded lower ground. Reference to the measuring rod in the photograph shows that the ground level near by has been lowered by at least a further 5 or 6 feet since the growth of this tamarisk-cone began. In the same fig. is seen in the foreground the debris of heavy timber which may mark the last remains of the gate leading through the east wall (cf. Serindia, i. p. 388).' (I.A. Map 29, D3).

msItem.title: Camels drinking at Alam-khoja-kol [or Uzun-kol].

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig 122: 'Camels being loaded with ice at Uzun-kol.' Alam-khoja-kol and Uzun-kol are close to one another: 'At the close of the first march from Abdal we passed our old camping place of 1906 near Alam-khoja-kol...finding this depression now quite dry, we had to move about a mile and a half to the east in order to find a lagoon, the Uzun-kol, containing ice...and here we took up our water-supply. Thick slabs of solid fresh-tasting ice were cut overnight, and packed in stout woollen bags, and nineteen of our camels were loaded with them in the morning...' (i, p. 181). (I.A. Map 30, C1).

msItem.title: View south from T. IV.a. showing line of wall and camp of 1907 in distance (Kabil on wall). [From near Toghrak-bulak.]

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig. 190: 'North-eastern corner of terminal basin of Su-lo-ho, with lines of limes agger, looking south from T.IV.a.' The watch tower T.IV.a. is located a little south of Toghrak-bulak (I.A. Map 35, C4). 'Fig. 190 shows the reed-covered north-eastern corner of the great marshy basin in which the Su-lo-ho terminates, as seen to the south of T.IV.a. In the foreground, at the foot of the steep clay terrace, there is seen the beginning of the Limes agger, built of reed fascines and stamped clay. The figure of the man standing marks its foot on the inside...Further on, the line of the wall, decayed into a mere low mound and overgrown with reeds, could be made out by the naked eye running straight south towards the large clay terrace on which my Camp 171a of 1907 had stood...' (i, 343, note).

msItem.title: [Watch tower] T. IV.a. from east. [near Toghrak-bulak.]

note.p: General view of tower. PUBLISHED: ' Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig. 194: 'Watch-tower T.IV.a. at western extremity of Tun-huang Limes.' (I.A. Map 35, C4). '...we have first in Fig. 194 the much-decayed watch-tower T.IV.a, built on a clay terrace overlooking the depression in whichwe may locate the terminal station of the wall and the 'Well of the Protector General'; cf. 'Serindia', ii. pp. 634 sqq.; above, p. 308.' (i, 343, note).

msItem.title: Basin of Su-lo-ho with yardangs seen from sand ridge looking west.

note.p: Looking across the terminal basin of the Su-lo River, with yardangs (wind-eroded terraces) in the distance. PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig. 188: 'View westwards across central part of dry lacustrine basin beyond Su-lo-ho termination.' Photograph probably taken from the area marked 'Ridge of sand 50 feet', in upper left corner of I.A. Map 35, C4.

msItem.title: T. IV.a. View to east-south-east with traces of wall of castrum. [South of Toghrak-bulak.]

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig. 192: 'View from tower T.IV.a. eastwards across terminal portion of [Dunhuang] Limes.' (I.A. Map 35, C4). 'In Fig. 192 the view from the clay terrace bearing T.IV.a lies to the ESE. In the foreground the straight narrow mound, covered with reeds, marks the line of the decayed Limes wall. The middle distance shows faintly the high banks of earth in which, I believe, we may recognize the decomposed clay ramparts of an ancient Chinese castrum...Far away in the distance the watch-towers T.IV.b and c can just be made out, rising above tongue-like projections of the gravel glacis.' (i, 343, note).

msItem.title: Mesha [mesa] panorama [from Camp] CXII (Section I). To south-west.

note.p: Left-hand section of three-part panoramic view taken from Camp cxii, continued in prints 445 and 451. See location note at print 445. PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig. 186: 'Mesas in ancient lacustrine basin beyond Su-lo-ho termination, looking west-north-west from Camp CXII.' (I.A. Map 35, C3, B3). Published version printed in reverse.

note.p: Duplicate of print 450, but printed in reverse.

note.p: Right-hand section of three-part panoramic view taken from Camp cxii, continued in prints 445 and 450. PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig. 185: 'Mesas in ancient lacustrine basin beyond Su-lo-ho termination, looking west from Camp CXII.' (I.A. Map 35, C3).

msItem.title: Mesha [mesa] panorama (Section III). West-north-west. North end terminal basin [of Su-lo-ho] and mesha [mesa] of fixing 14/3/14.
Mesha [mesa] panorama (Section III). West-north-west. North end terminal basin [of Su-lo-ho] and mesha [mesa] of fixing 14/3/14.
Wall & T. XIII (ponies) seen from east. [near Yu-men.]

note.p: View along the line of the wall towards the tower in the distance, with a pony grazing on the skyline. PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig. 200: 'Line of Limes wall near Tower T.XIII.' (I.A. Map 35, D4). This section of the Limes is situated just east of Yu-men. 'Figs. 200 and 201 [print 454] bring before our eyes the remarkable state of preservation in which the line of the wall, built here as along most sections of the Limes west of Tun-huang of layers of reed fascines and stamped clay, has survived for some little distance east of T.XIII. As seen by the figures standing at its foot, it still rises in places to a height of over 10 feet above the sand and gravel heaped up at its foot...' (i, 344, note).

msItem.title: T. VII from south-east. Footholes and holes for ladder. [Watch tower T.VII, Dunhuang Limes, south-east of Toghrak-bulak.]

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig. 204: 'Watch-tower T.VII, Tun-huang Limes, seen from south-west.' (I.A. Map 35, D4). 'In Fig. 204 this tower T.VII appears as seen from the south-west, with the upper portion of the south face still showing rough foot-holes on the plastered surface intended to assist a person climbing to the top. The holes on either side once carried beams to secure the ropes that had to serve as hand-rails. Along the north-east corner the ends of thick ropes of twisted reeds are exposed, which, embedded in the stamped clay, helped to bind together posts of toghrak wood reinforcing the structure...' (i, 344, note).

msItem.title: Line of wall and track seen from T. XIII towards east. [Dunhuang Limes near Yu-men.]

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig. 201: 'Remains of Limes stretching east of Tower T.XIII.' (I.A. Map 35, D4). See note at print 452.

msItem.title: T. III. Line of wall towards T. VII (Kabil). [South-east of Toghrak-bulak.]

note.p: View from hillside looking along the line of the wall, with Kabil standing in the foreground. PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig. 191: 'Line of Limes wall stretching eastwards from watch-tower T.III.' (I.A. Map 35, C4-D4). 'Fig. 191 shows the stretch of the Limes wall where it descends from the gravel plateau near T.III and extends in very fair preservation for a distance of about three miles across the depression towards the next watch-tower T.VII.' (i, 344, note).

msItem.title: Stacks of fascines to north of T. XI from south-east (Kabil). [East of Chong-kol.]

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 1, fig. 193: 'Petrified stacks of fascines outside Watch-tower T.XI, Tun-huang Limes.' (I.A. Map 35, D4). 'In Figs. 193 and 198 [print 461] we see stacks of reed fascines, more or less petrified through the action of salt, as they rise in rows, quincunx fashion, near the watch-towers T.XI and T.XIII respectively. As fully explained in Serindia, ii. pp. 677 sqq., these regular stacks were primarily intended to keep material conveniently ready for the lighting of signal fires.' (i, 344, note).

'On the left bank of the river, at a point a little below our Camp 122, we found the mouth of a small Nullah that descends from the Ean-shan-tzu spur occupied by a ruined temple, well built and of recent appearance...Its name was subsequently given as Lao-chun-miao...It had apparently been destroyed during the Tungan rebellion.' msItem.title: Malum, Mongol, with his horse.

note.p: Full-length standing portrait. Malum was hired as a Turki interpreter at Dunhuang: ''Malum'...proved a hardy and fairly intelligent fellow, dressed in a monk's red garb and possessed of some education. In spite of a somewhat irascible temper which involved him more than once in quarrels with the Torgut herdsmen, &c., encountered on the Etsin-gol, he served us well, both on the march and during the excavations at Khara-khoto. Carried, with all that he needed, by his sturdy Mongolian mount, he caused the minimum of encumbrance.' (i, 372). Probably photographed on the same occasion as print 482, in the vicinity of Wang-shan-tzu. (I.A. Map 40, A4).

'...It [the Limes wall] presented itself here as a low mound half-smothered by drift-sand, but unmistakenly disclosing its character by a thick layer of flat tamarisk branches covering its top...' (i, 398).

msItem.title: Su-chou, east town wall and mountains from north-east on lake.
Torgut Beili with two Begs. [Tawun-tora.]

note.p: Full-length seated portrait, with the two other figures standing behind him. Photograph taken when the Beili visited Stein at Tawun-tora: 'At Tawun-tora I was obliged to make a two days' halt, May 24th to 25th, in order to receive and return the visit of the chief or 'Beili' of the Etsin-gol Torguts, encamped some eight miles to the north...The Mongol chief proved a kindly, if somewhat weak-looking person...and under the influence of the strong recommendation received from the Tao-t'ai of Su-chou seemed willing enough to offer what assistance his resources would permit. That these resources were modest enough I was able to realize, when on May 25th I paid my visit to the 'Beili's' camp at a place known as Dashoba, not far from the westernmost branch of the Umne-gol...' (i, 432-433). See also print 512. (I.A. Map 45, C1).

Back court of Lai-lai-maio [at Sun-nai-pao].
Lai-lai-maio (back court) [at Sun-nai-pao].

note.p: View of courtyard and temple. '...A short distance east of the village marked on the map as Sun-nai-pao [in a note Stein casts some doubt on the correctness of this name], we made a night's halt at a large and interesting temple. It is known as Lai-lai-miao (?) and is situated near high dunes. It seemed fairly old and the sand was invading all of its numerous courts and shrines. With its elaborate and graceful wooden pavilions, balustraded passages, and bridges connecting different shrines it recalled more closely the architecture of celestial mansions mansions as represented in the Ch'ien-fo-tung paintings of the Western Paradise than any of the structures seen by me on Chinese ground. Its remains when completely abandoned to the drift-sand may provide an interesting 'site' for some future excavator a thousand years or more hence. It is evidently a cherished place of pilgrimage for the inhabitants of the flourishing walled villages by the [Kan-chou] river, and I regret not to have been able to secure an account of its origin and tradition.' (i, 520-21). (I.A. Map 46, A2).

msItem.title: Coalpits of Miao [Mou-wo] from north-east.

note.p: 'There we found Lal Singh duly encamped by the side of one of the two wells dug in the dry bed passing below the coal-pits. Two or three houses half in ruins marked the quarters of the people from Chin-t'a and Mao-mei who until recent years used to come here for short periods in the winter to gather coal from the shallow diggings. Of this coal specimens were secured...The pits extend irregularly for about a mile to the west of the stream-bed and seem to be worked to a depth of 15 to 17 feet from the surface, in narrow ditches.' (i, 524). (I.A. Map 42, B3).

msItem.title: Masib, Ahmad*, Haji, Abdullah, Kara-khoja outlaws at Panopa shelter huts. *Skull seen in Jan. 1915.

note.p: Full-length portrait of the four men, standing in a line with rifles. 'While halting for the night I had an interesting opportunity of becoming acquainted with a small party of well-armed outlaws from Kara-khoja of whose presence on this much-frequented mountain route I had already been warned at Jimasa...They were the 'die-hard' remnant of a large party of Kara-khoja cultivators, who having had a long-standing dispute over some lands with neighbours of Astana...had about six months before attacked and killed the Muhammadan Jisa, the local revenue official, whom they believed to have brought about the defeat of their rightful claims...They were well armed with Mauser rifles, for since the revolution of 1911-12 it had become easy to purchase arms and ammunition from the Chinese garrison at Turfan...Since removing themselves to a region outside the Turfan command, the four heroes had remained wholly unmolested. They were now maintaining themselves in comparative comfort at Pa-no-p'a by the receipt of charitable gifts from sympathizing fellow Muslims and of blackmail from other wayfarers...Ahmad's wish to meet me again during my winter's stay in Turfan was to be realised in a fashion rather different from that he had in mind; for, on returning from Urumchi in the first days of January, I was greeted by his shrivelled black head stuck up on a high pole outside the gate of the Yang-shahr of Turfan...' (ii, 560, note). (I.A. Map 28, B1).

Yetti-kiz-khojam Mazar at Yutogh seen from east.

note.p: 'After proceeding to the south-east for about two miles to the edge of the main cultivation and then crossing a bare gravel plateau, we dropped down to a narrow strip of fields tilled by the dozen households of Yutogh and situated along the deep-cut bed of the stream coming from Khando. Close above its left bank a gravel plateau rises very steeply to a height of about eighty feet, bearing on its top the Mazar, known as Yetti-kiz-khojam, 'the Seven Holy Maids,' and visited as a place of pilgrimage.' (ii, 610). (I.A. Map 28, D3).

msItem.title: Afrazgul and Hassan A. [Akhun] arrived with camels from Lop Desert at Yardang-bulak.

note.p: Group of men and camels posed for camera. 'On March 13th I was obliged to make a day's halt at Yardang-bulak in order to let the camels have a rest and a good feed after their privations in the desert, before setting out west for the ruins of Ying-p'an. Busy as I was kept with writing and mapping work, my thoughts turned anxiously to Afraz-gul's little party, now fully a week overdue. After midday, I thought I could hear the faint sound of distant camel bells...leass than half an hour later Hassan Akhun appeared in triumph from behind the screening gravel ridges south-eastwards, bringing the best of our hardy camels all safe and sound, though gaunt-looking. Soon after I had the great satisfaction of welcoming Afraz-gul with his plane-table, travel-worn indeed...but fit and keen all the same...' (ii, 741). (I.A. Map 29, A3).

'I used my single day's halt at Kucha on April 30th to visit the large but badly decayed ruined mound known as Kotluk-ordu, where Mir Sharif and other local informants stated that the famous Bower manuscript and other important texts in Sanskrit and Kuchean, brought to India in 1891 and subsequently edited by the late Dr Hoernle, had been discovered.' (ii, 818). (I.A. Map 17, B1).

Awkward corner aboveTanimaz River, beyond Bashur Nullah, above Rukhj.

note.p: View looking along the path above the river. 'It thus became possible on August 12th to push on to the Bartang valley after a night spent at the small Tajik hamlet of Pasor...The track, difficult in places for laden animals, kept close to the river wherever the steep banks overhanging it left room, or else crossed high terraces. On one of these the small village of Rukhj was passed; its green fields presented a refreshing contrast to the utterly bare slopes around.' (ii, 853). PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 2, fig. 369:' Crossing rock debris thrown down by earthquake near Palez, Tanimaz Valley.'

Kokan-Beg, Ming-bashi of Kara-kul, with his son, at Kara-chim.

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 2, fig. 356: 'Kokan beg, headman of Kirghiz about Great Kara-kul.' Kokan Beg seated on horse, his son standing in front: 'The necessity of securing fresh transport and a fresh guide for our further move obliged me next day to seek contact with Kokan Beg, the headman of the Kirghiz who graze about the Great Kara-kul lake eastwards...On our descent down the wide gently sloping valley I was met by Kokan Beg, a fine looking man, and conducted by him to a small summer camp of some of his men at Kara-chim at an elevation of some 13,700 feet. From that capable headman I was able to secure useful advice with regard to our future route.' (ii, 852).

note.p: 'Old cultivation terraces were met with at Yol-mazar at an elevation of about 12,500 feet. About three miles lower we passed on the left bank the mouth of a wide grassy valley, known as Issik-bulak from a hot spring...'

msItem.title: Fatteh Ali Shah's Kala at Kala-i-Panja, from north (enlarged).

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 2, fig. 398: 'Kala-i-Panja, seen from right bank of Ab-i-Panja.' 'Four miles below Zang we passed in full view of Kala-i-Panja, the seat of the Mirs of Wakhan in modern times and now occupied by the chief Afghan post in the valley. Counting only some 15 households and situated by the side of a huge fan of detritus, this 'capital' of Afghan Wakhan looked a very desolate place.' (ii, 865).

msItem.title: Warang fort ruin and village from south-east (Rahmatullah Beg in fore).
Ihsan Karim Ali Shah, Pir of Wakhan Maulais, at Wanukut.

note.p: Full-length seated portrait, similar to print 894. 'At the hamlet of Wenukut I was able to pay a visit to Ihsan Karim Ali Shah, the chief 'Pir' of the Ismailias of Wakhan, who was staying there to perform faith-healing on a sick 'Murid' or devotee. The old man, worshipped as a great saint, claimed an age of well over a hundred years, and his bodily state seemed to support this. Yet his mental faculties were not impaired, and to my surprise he furnished exact data which left no doubt about his having at his home been the host of Captain Wood, when in the winter of 1838 he was on his way to the Pamirs. He had clear recollections, too, of the tyrannical rule of Sultan Murad of Kunduz, often named in Wood's classic narrative.' (ii, 866).

msItem.title: Zangibar fort seen from north-east on ridge. [Zang.]

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 2, fig. 397: 'Hindukush peaks above Ishmarg, seen across Ab-i-Panja.' View along river towards mountains. '...farther down [the valley] opposite Ishmarg...and at other points in the valley, grand vistas opened to the south. Towering above narrow side valleys, and seemingly quite near, magnificient ice-clad peaks of the Hindukush main range could be seen, looking just like peaks of jade or silver, as Sung-yun and his fellow-pilgrim Hui-sheng describe them, on their passage down the 'kingdom of Po-ho' or Wakhan, A.D. 519.' (ii, 865).

note.p: 'It was about two miles beyond Sendiw that we encountered the first and only serious obstacle to traffic within Shakh-dara. Here a very steep descent of some 200 feet had to be made over 'Rafaks' down to the left bank of the river, making it necessary to unload ponies.' (ii, 882)

msItem.title: Ruined dwellings of Kafir Kala, Bidegh [Bidech], from west, with view up towards Sendiw.

note.p: View of ruins, with the Shakh-dara river in the background. 'Here at the grazing ground of Bidech, a terrace rising about 80 feet above the riverine jungle is covered over an area of about 150 yards by 120 with massive walls of ruined dwellings, to which tradition ascribes 'Kafir' origin. The masonry of flat unhewn stones set in mud plaster shows considerable solidity and is certainly superior to any seen by me in Shughni buildings...' (ii, 881). PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 2, fig. 417: 'Ruined dwellings at Bidech, Shakh-dara, Shughnan.'

note.p: General view of glacier, with horseman in foreground. ' According to the headman's statement the glacier had considerably advanced since his father's youth, and so also had the smaller glacier of Ferokh-sangau...which was passed at an elevation of some 1,700 feet below the snout of Shitok-lazar. It stretches down from WSW into a perfectly level basin, about half a mile long and a quarter across.' (ii, 884). PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 2, fig. 420: 'Ferokh-sangau Glacier below Shitok-lazar, Roshan.'

Kala-i-Wamar Fort from river bank, looking north-east.

note.p: 'The castle in whichthe sons or brothers of the Shughnan Mirs, deputed to govern Roshan, used to reside retains its thick outer walls of rough stonework. They are reinforced by large tree trunks set in it, after a fashion from the Indian NW frontier right away to the Oxus. The interior, badly decayed, showed no distinctive local features.' (ii, 887).

msItem.title: Fort of Kala-i-Wamar seen from north-east (Nazar Dad in fore).
Family group of Arbab's mother and daughter, Kala-i-Wamar. Grand-daughter with head turned.

note.p: Group posed against stone wall beneath tree. PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 2, fig. 426: 'Group of Roshani family, Kala-i-Wamar. (See p. 886, note 2).' The note reads, in part: 'The women of Roshan are said to be famous for good looks and particularly for fairness of complexion. I had a wayside chance of convincing myself that this reputation was probably well-deserved, when, in company with the Ak-sakal of Kala-i-Wamar, I passed three generations of his family assembled in a group...near his home. Wife and mother were as fair of face as if they had been ladies of Europe. The elder of the two little girls in the group served to show how here, too, fashion endeavours to exaggerate favours bestowed by nature; for her grandmother was just busily engaged in smearing her pretty rosy cheeks with some wild berries intended to bleach the skin.'

msItem.title: Roshanis Nos. 254-263 (Gilgiti slave on extreme right sitting). [Kala-i-Wamar.]

note.p: Group portrait of ten men and Stein's dog Dash. Stein records that during his stay of a day at Kala-i-Wamar, he carried out 'much anthropometrical and other work'. (ii, 886).

msItem.title: Decorated door and window above it in Ming-bashi Mir Shukrak's house, Kala-i-Wamar (window brought away).

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 2, fig. 449: 'Old wood-carving at entrance of Ming-bashi's house, Kala-i-Wamar. For wood-carving of window, see pl. LXVIII.' The view shows the carved wood doorway, with the window above held in place by two men. 'I used the opportunity for close examination of Ming-bashi Mir Shikrak's house, a typical Roshan dwelling, situated about half a mile from the fort towards the village of Barzut. A piece of old wood-carving had been brought to me from it, and on inquiry I found that it belonged to a fine double-arched window frame which, owing to intended alterations, had been removed from above the main entrance and put with the lumber. The photograph...shows it as restored to its rightful place, and Pl. LXVIII as temporarily set up at the British Museum. The ornamentation of both window and door, though manifestly Saracenic in its main design, shows also elements of late Hellenistic origin, curiously Byzantine in appearance...' (ii, 886).

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Innermost Asia', vol. 2, fig. 433: 'View down Oxus gorge below Amurn, Yazgulam.' 'On moving through the gloomy gorges of the Oxus below Yazgulam...by the new bridle-path, blasted out of the perpendicular rock wall or leading over boldly built narrow balconies, it was easy to realize why the passage of this succession of awrinz was formerly risky even for local hillmen and quite impossible for the carriage of loads...' (ii, 889).
